statement.tex: %text A dietician wishes to mix two types of foods in a such a way that the vitamin contents of the mixture contains atleast 8 units of vitamin A and 10 units of vitamin C. Food X contains 2 units/kg of vitamin A and 1 unit/kg of vitamin C while food Y contains 1 unit/kg of vitamin A and 2 units/kg of vitamin C. It costs ₹ 5/kg to purchase food X and ₹ 7/kg to purchase food Y. Determine the minimum cost of such a mixture. Formulate the above as a LPP and solve it graphically. %

\\ %text Given the following variables, have the constraints and the objective function been written correctly? % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Variable} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline Q_X & \text{Quantity of X needed (kg)} \\ \hline Q_Y & \text{Quantity of Y needed (kg)}\\ \hline \end{tabular}
\\ %text Have the constraints from Step 1, and hence the \underline\text{feasible} region and points been shown correctly below? %
\\ %text Given the three feasible points - B,C and E - the lowest cost mixture that will fullfill all vitamin requirements is the following. \textbf{Right or wrong?} %

reason.tex:
%text First, take stock of all the facts given in the question.
If we use $Q_X$ kg of food X and $Q_Y$ kg of food Y, then the \underline{\text{total vitamin content}} in the mixture will be as follows.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{X} & \text{Y} & \text{Total} \\ \hline \text{Vit. A} & \text{2 units/kg} & \text{1 unit/kg} & 2Q_X + Q_Y \\ \hline \text{Vit. C} & \text{1 unit/kg} & \text{2 units/kg} & Q_X + 2Q_Y \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
Moreover % \begin{tabular}{|c|l|} \hline \text{Constraint} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline 2Q_X + Q_Y \geq 8 & \text{Atleast 8 units of vit. A} \\ \hline Q_X + 2Q_Y \geq 10 & \text{Atleast 10 units of vit. C} \\ \hline 5Q_X + 7Q_Y & \text{Total cost (minimize)} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

%text Notice that in the $Q_X-Q_Y$ plot, only points \underline\text{like point $r$} satisfy \underline\text{both} of the following conditions
% \begin{align} 2Q_x + Q_Y &\geq 8 \\ Q_X + 2Q_Y &\geq 10 \end{align} %text
All other points (like p,q and s) satisfy only one (or none) of the constraints.
Hence, with the feasible region as shown, the only \underline\text{feasible points} are $B,C$ and $E$. %

%text The coordinates of point $C$ can be gotten by solving the following equations. % \begin{align} 2Q_X &+ Q_Y = 8 \\ Q_X &+ 2Q_Y = 10 \\ \implies Q_X &=2\text{ and }Q_Y = 4 \end{align}\\ %text
And from the graph in Step 2, one can also see that $B=(0,8)$ and $E=(10,0)$. Hence,
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Point} & (Q_X, Q_Y) & \text{Cost}=5Q_X + 7Q_Y \\ \hline B & (0,8) & ₹ 56 \\ \hline C & (2,4) & ₹ 38 \\ \hline E & (10,0) & ₹ 50 \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ %text
The \underline\text{lowest cost} mixture therefore consists of 2 kg of food X and 4 kg of food Y at a \underline\text{total cost} of ₹ 38. %
